hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad: I used to enter upon Aisha without permission. When I reached puberty (احتلمت), I began greeting (making salaam) and asking permission. She recognized my voice and said to me: 'O Uday, did you do this yourself?' I said: 'Yes, Mother.' She said: 'Enter, my dear son.' So she turned towards me and asked me about my father and his companions, and I informed her. Then she asked me about what they had sent me to her with.

I came to her and called out to her from behind the curtain. She said: 'Did you do this yourself, O foolish one?' I said: 'My father says, what necessitates ghusl?' She said: 'When the two things meet' (meaning sexual intercourse).

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Isra'il: I used to think when I saw Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad that he was indeed a noble Arab nobleman in his clothing, perfume, and mount. And I saw him riding upon a Bardhawn (a type of horse). In another narration: Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad used to come riding on a Bardhawn. In another narration: I saw Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad wearing fine silk (Khazz). In another narration: I saw Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad dyeing with henna. In another narration from Talq ibn Ghannam al-Nakha'i on authority of his father Ghannam ibn Talq: There was a pre-Islamic alliance between us and al-Aswad ibn Yazid, so Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad seldom went on a journey or returned from a journey except that he came to us to greet us, preserving that alliance.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sinan ibn Habib al-Sulami: I went out with Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad to the bridge (al-Qantar), and whenever he passed by a Jew or a Christian, he would greet him. I said to him: 'You greet these people even though they are people of polytheism?' He said: 'Indeed, greeting is the sign of a Muslim, so I wanted them to know that I am a Muslim.' In another narration from al-Hasan ibn Ubaydillah: Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad used to lead us in prayer on the night of Eid, and he used to soak his feet in water while he was fasting. In another narration from Zubayd: Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Aswad used to lead his people in twelve units of Tarawih prayer in Ramadan, and between every two units he would pray twelve units for himself, and he would recite a third of the Quran each night. And he used to lead them in prayer on the night of Eid, saying: 'Indeed, it is a night of celebration.'

They said: Salim died during the caliphate of Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz in the year 100 or 101 AH, though Abu Nu'aym said: Rather he died before that during the caliphate of Sulayman ibn Abd al-Malik. He was trustworthy and narrated many hadiths.

Abu al-Bakhtari said: 'Do not do that, for I am a man from the mawali (clients/freedmen). Appoint over you a man from the Arabs.' They said: Abu al-Bakhtari witnessed with Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Ash'ath on the day of al-Dujail, and he was killed on that day in the year 83 AH (702 CE).

hadiths.english_translation: Abdullah ibn Idris said, from Shu'bah: I asked al-Hakam ibn Utaybah about Zadhaan, he said: 'Narrate much (from him).' I asked Salamah ibn Kuhayl, he said: 'Abu al-Bakhtari is more pleasing to me than him.' Abu al-Bakhtari narrated many hadiths and reported some as mursal (suspended chains), and he narrated from the companions of the Prophet ﷺ but did not hear from any of the major scholars. So whatever of his hadiths were with direct hearing (samaa'), it is good (hasan), and whatever was suspended (mursal), it is weak (daif).
